name: Turku
fun_fact: Fun fact: Turku is Finland's oldest city (founded in 1229) and self-proclaimed 'restaurant capital of Finland' - it became the first Finnish city outside Helsinki to earn a Michelin star (Kaskis restaurant in 2019).

hero_dishes.name: Finnish Salmon
hero_dishes.description: Wild-caught Baltic salmon, often smoked or grilled, served with seasonal vegetables and dill cream sauce
hero_dishes.origin_story: Turku's location on the Archipelago Sea gives it access to pristine Baltic salmon. Finnish smoking traditions date back centuries when fish needed to be preserved for harsh winters. Today's preparations balance tradition with modern techniques.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Kaskis (Michelin-starred, perched on KaskenmÃ¤ki hill - seasonal menus with local produce), GrÃ¤dda (Imperial wooden house from 1832)

hero_dishes.name: Traditional Finnish Forest Flavors
hero_dishes.description: Dishes featuring wild mushrooms, berries, and game from Finnish forests - chanterelles, lingonberries, elk, and reindeer
hero_dishes.origin_story: Finnish cuisine is deeply connected to foraging. The 'everyman's right' (jokamiehenoikeus) allows anyone to pick wild berries and mushrooms, creating a culture where forest ingredients are treasured. Turku's restaurants elevate these humble ingredients to fine dining.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Kaskis (36-seat gem showcasing southwest Finland's forest bounty), Suomalainen Pohja ('Finnish Base' - rustic hearty dishes with local ingredients)

hero_dishes.name: Archipelago Whitefish
hero_dishes.description: Delicate whitefish from the surrounding archipelago, simply prepared to showcase freshness
hero_dishes.origin_story: The Turku Archipelago Sea contains over 20,000 islands. Local whitefish from these pure waters has fed Turku for centuries. The long growing season and mineral-rich soil nearby also produce vibrant vegetables to accompany the fish.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Suomalainen Pohja (cozy wood-accented interior like a Finnish summer house), riverside restaurants along River Aura

hero_dishes.name: Finnish Nordic Cuisine
hero_dishes.description: Modern interpretations of Finnish classics using hyperlocal ingredients - from sea buckthorn to rye bread
hero_dishes.origin_story: Turku hosted the MICHELIN Guide Ceremony for all Nordic Countries in June 2023, cementing its place as a culinary destination. Chefs celebrate pure ingredients from the archipelago's long growing season.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Kaskis (first Michelin star outside Helsinki), Restaurant Kakolanruusu (in old Kakola prison courtyard - Finland's most fascinating setting)

signature_drinks.name: Finnish Berry Liqueurs
signature_drinks.description: Cloudberry, lingonberry, and sea buckthorn liqueurs capturing summer's brief intensity
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served as digestifs or mixed into cocktails. These capture the essence of Finnish summer when berries ripen in 24-hour daylight. Each berry has distinct flavors - cloudberries are golden and complex, sea buckthorn is tart and bright.

signature_drinks.name: Finnish Craft Beer
signature_drinks.description: Local microbreweries creating innovative Nordic-style beers with foraged ingredients
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Enjoyed at riverside terraces during summer months. Turku's beer scene incorporates local berries, herbs, and even spruce tips into unique brews. Paired with traditional Finnish foods.

food_culture_notes: Turku's culinary strength comes from the surrounding archipelago's pure ingredients and long growing season
Summer brings riverside terrace dining along the River Aura - a cherished tradition when Finns emerge from winter
The city emphasizes 'New Nordic' cuisine - local, seasonal, simple preparations that let quality ingredients shine
Note: Mustamakkara (blood sausage) is actually a Tampere specialty, not Turku - it's a common mix-up between Finland's two major southern cities
